channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: AI-enhanced night-vision lets users see in the dark
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02424-9

Night-vision technology gets a boost from machine learning, and the mysterious link between COVID-19 and type-1 diabetes.
item.dc:title: AI-enhanced night-vision lets users see in the dark
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: Curry has tempted diners in southeast Asia for more than 1,500 years
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02340-y

Scientists identify traces of ginger, nutmeg and other spices on ancient kitchen tools that were found in Vietnam.
item.dc:title: Curry has tempted diners in southeast Asia for more than 1,500 years

item.title: Evolutionary histories of breast cancer and related clones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06333-9

By using phylogenetic analyses of multiple microdissected samples from both cancer and non-cancer lesions, unique evolutionary histories of breast cancers harbouring a common driver alteration are shown, providing new insight into how breast cancer evolves.
item.dc:title: Evolutionary histories of breast cancer and related clones
item.dc:creator: Tomomi Nishimura

item.title: Sub-1.4 cm<sup>3</sup> capsule for detecting labile inflammatory biomarkers in situ
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06369-x

A biosensor comprising bacteria engineered to respond to transient inflammatory signals has been packaged with electronic readout and transmission circuits in a small device that could be swallowed to monitor gastrointestinal health.
item.dc:title: Sub-1.4 cm<sup>3</sup> capsule for detecting labile inflammatory biomarkers in situ
item.dc:creator: M. E. Inda-Webb

item.title: Global hotspots of traded phylogenetic and functional diversity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06371-3

Using a global dataset of traded species, it is found that the highest levels of traded phylogenetic and functional diversity are from tropical regions, where high numbers of evolutionary distinct and globally endangered species occur.
item.dc:title: Global hotspots of traded phylogenetic and functional diversity
item.dc:creator: Liam J. Hughes
Mike R. Massam
Oscar Morton
Felicity A. Edwards
Brett R. Scheffers
David P. Edwards

item.title: Rewiring cancer drivers to activate apoptosis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06348-2

A new class of molecules can recruit downstream transcription factors or endogenous cancer drivers to cell death promoters and activate the expression of these genes.
item.dc:title: Rewiring cancer drivers to activate apoptosis
item.dc:creator: Sai Gourisankar
Andrey Krokhotin
Wenzhi Ji
Xiaofan Liu
Chiung-Ying Chang
Samuel H. Kim

Hannes Vogel
Tinghu Zhang
Michael R. Green
Nathanael S. Gray
Gerald R. Crabtree

item.title: Small protein modules dictate prophage fates during polylysogeny
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06376-y

Prophage lysogeny-to-lysis transitions are controlled by regulatory modules consisting of transcription factors and partner small proteins that are activated through DNA-damage-independent pathways, including by quorum sensing, and these modules determine inter-prophage competition outcomes.
item.dc:title: Small protein modules dictate prophage fates during polylysogeny
item.dc:creator: Justin E. Silpe
Olivia P. Duddy
Grace E. Johnson
Grace A. Beggs
Fatima A. Hussain
Kevin J. Forsberg
Bonnie L. Bassler

item.title: Accelerating the energy transition towards photovoltaic and wind in China
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06180-8

To meet China’s goal of carbon neutrality by 2060, substantial investment in upgrading power systems needs to be made to optimize the deployment of new photovoltaic and wind power plants.
item.dc:title: Accelerating the energy transition towards photovoltaic and wind in China
item.dc:creator: Yijing Wang
Rong Wang
Katsumasa Tanaka
Philippe Ciais
Josep Penuelas
Yves Balkanski

item.title: Subsecond periodic radio oscillations in a microquasar
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06336-6

Two instances of approximately 5-Hz transient periodic oscillation features from the source detected in the 1.05- to 1.45-GHz radio band that occurred in January 2021 and June 2022 are reported.
item.dc:title: Subsecond periodic radio oscillations in a microquasar
item.dc:creator: Pengfu Tian
Ping Zhang

Na Sai

item.title: Extensive pedigrees reveal the social organization of a Neolithic community
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06350-8

The burial community at Gurgy ‘les Noisats’ (France) was genetically connected by two main pedigrees, spanning seven generations, that were patrilocal and patrilineal, with evidence for female exogamy and exchange with genetically close neighbouring groups.
item.dc:title: Extensive pedigrees reveal the social organization of a Neolithic community
item.dc:creator: Maïté Rivollat
Adam Benjamin Rohrlach
Harald Ringbauer
Ainash Childebayeva
Fanny Mendisco

Wolfgang Haak

item.title: Neural basis for fasting activation of the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06358-0

Fasting-activated hypothalamic AgRP-expressing neurons trigger fasting-induced hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis activation through projections to the paraventricular hypothalamus, where they activate CRH neurons by presynaptically inhibiting the terminals of tonically active GABAergic afferents from the bed nucleus of the stria terminalis.
item.dc:title: Neural basis for fasting activation of the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal axis
item.dc:creator: Amelia M. Douglass
Jon M. Resch
Joseph C. Madara
Hakan Kucukdereli
Ofer Yizhar
Abhinav Grama
Masahito Yamagata
Zongfang Yang
Bradford B. Lowell

item.title: Evolutionarily divergent mTOR remodels translatome for tissue regeneration
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06365-1

Rapid activation of protein synthesis in the axolotl highlights the unanticipated impact of a translatome on orchestrating the early steps of wound healing and provides a missing link in our understanding of vertebrate regenerative potential.
item.dc:title: Evolutionarily divergent mTOR remodels translatome for tissue regeneration
item.dc:creator: Olena Zhulyn
Hannah D. Rosenblatt
Leila Shokat
Shizhong Dai
Duygu Kuzuoglu-Öztürk
Zijian Zhang
Davide Ruggero
Kevan M. Shokat
Maria Barna

item.title: Heat-assisted detection and ranging
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06174-6

Heat-assisted detection and ranging is experimentally shown to see texture and depth through darkness as if it were day, and also perceives decluttered physical attributes beyond RGB or thermal vision.
item.dc:title: Heat-assisted detection and ranging
item.dc:creator: Fanglin Bao
Xueji Wang
Shree Hari Sureshbabu
Gautam Sreekumar
Liping Yang
Vaneet Aggarwal
Vishnu N. Boddeti
Zubin Jacob

item.title: Rift-induced disruption of cratonic keels drives kimberlite volcanism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06193-3

Most kimberlites erupting in the past billion years on Earth did so about 30 million years after continental breakup, with dynamical and analytical models suggesting a control from rifting-related mantle delamination.
item.dc:title: Rift-induced disruption of cratonic keels drives kimberlite volcanism
item.dc:creator: Thomas M. Gernon
Stephen M. Jones
Sascha Brune
Thea K. Hincks
Martin R. Palmer
John C. Schumacher
Rebecca M. Primiceri
Matthew Field
William L. Griffin
Suzanne Y. O’Reilly
Derek Keir
Christopher J. Spencer
Andrew S. Merdith
Anne Glerum

item.title: Earth’s evolving geodynamic regime recorded by titanium isotopes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06304-0

Titanium isotope measurements for chondrites, ancient terrestrial mantle-derived lavas and modern ocean island basalts imply the preservation of a primordial lower-mantle reservoir for most of Earth’s geologic history.
item.dc:title: Earth’s evolving geodynamic regime recorded by titanium isotopes
item.dc:creator: Zhengbin Deng
Martin Schiller
Matthew G. Jackson
Marc-Alban Millet
Lu Pan
Katrine Nikolajsen
Nikitha S. Saji
Dongyang Huang
Martin Bizzarro

item.title: Universal equation of state for wave turbulence in a quantum gas
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06240-z

Equilibrium-like state variables, related by an equation of state, are identified in a study of turbulent cascade of matter waves in a far-from-equilibrium ultracold atomic Bose gas.
item.dc:title: Universal equation of state for wave turbulence in a quantum gas
item.dc:creator: Lena H. Dogra
Gevorg Martirosyan
Timon A. Hilker
Jake A. P. Glidden
Jiří Etrych
Alec Cao
Christoph Eigen
Robert P. Smith
Zoran Hadzibabic

item.title: CAR T therapy beyond cancer: the evolution of a living drug
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06243-w

The rationale behind chimaeric antigen receptor T cell therapy is reviewed, and current challenges in oncology, preliminary reports in noncancerous diseases and relevant emerging technologies are discussed.
item.dc:title: CAR T therapy beyond cancer: the evolution of a living drug
item.dc:creator: Daniel J. Baker
Zoltan Arany
Joseph A. Baur
Jonathan A. Epstein
Carl H. June

item.title: Structure of an endogenous mycobacterial MCE lipid transporter
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06366-0

Proteins of the Mycobacterium smegmatis Mce1 system assemble to form an elongated ABC transporter complex that is long enough to span the impermeable mycobacterial cell envelope.
item.dc:title: Structure of an endogenous mycobacterial MCE lipid transporter
item.dc:creator: James Chen
Alice Fruhauf
Catherine Fan
Jackeline Ponce
Beatrix Ueberheide
Gira Bhabha
Damian C. Ekiert

item.title: Increased occurrences of consecutive La Niña events under global warming
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06236-9

Analysis of climate models under future greenhouse-gas forcings shows that the frequency of consecutive La Niña events will increase, driven by ocean–atmosphere feedbacks that slow the heat recharge of the equatorial Pacific.
item.dc:title: Increased occurrences of consecutive La Niña events under global warming
item.dc:creator: Tao Geng
Fan Jia
Wenju Cai
Lixin Wu
Bolan Gan
Zhao Jing
Shujun Li
Michael J. McPhaden

item.title: Mammary duct luminal epithelium controls adipocyte thermogenic programme
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06361-5

In mice, sympathetic nerves associated with female mammary glands control the secretion of thermogenesis-controlling factors by epithelial cells in the adipocyte niche, revealing sex-specific differences in adipose thermogenesis.
item.dc:title: Mammary duct luminal epithelium controls adipocyte thermogenic programme
item.dc:creator: Sanil Patel
Njeri Z. R. Sparman
Douglas Arneson
Alexandra Alvarsson
Luís C. Santos
Samuel J. Duesman

item.title: Eight laws I wound up breaking while attempting to restore the timeline
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02372-4

Time travel is harder than it looks.
item.dc:title: Eight laws I wound up breaking while attempting to restore the timeline
item.dc:creator: P. A. Cornell

item.title: Shade is an essential solution for hotter cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02311-3

One of the most effective ways to keep people cool is often neglected in urban planning. Cities must work to provide cover and reverse the ‘shade deserts’ common in low-income communities.
item.dc:title: Shade is an essential solution for hotter cities
item.dc:creator: V. Kelly Turner
Ariane Middel
Jennifer K. Vanos

item.title: Structure sheds light on a lipid-transport machine in mycobacteria
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02184-6

To cause tuberculosis, the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis must obtain nutrients from host cells. This is facilitated at least in part by protein complexes known as transporters. The structure of one such transporter reveals how its constituent subunits assemble into a large complex that enables lipids to be transported into the bacterium.
item.dc:title: Structure sheds light on a lipid-transport machine in mycobacteria

item.title: Daily briefing: A new Turing test for artificial intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02439-2

The race is on for new ways to assess ChatGPT and other large language models. Plus, controversial claims about ancient humans test eLife’s revamped peer-review model.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: A new Turing test for artificial intelligence
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Bias in science: how to fight the good fight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02434-7

Good luck trying to dismantle entrenched structures and processes, says Athene Donald — but don’t give up, support is out there.
item.dc:title: Bias in science: how to fight the good fight
item.dc:creator: Athene Donald

item.title: Salamanders’ regenerative potential might be driven by a specific protein variant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02111-9

Axolotls — aquatic salamanders with an exceptional regenerative ability — rapidly increase their production of proteins in response to wounds. An axolotl-specific evolutionary divergence in a key protein called mTOR might drive this protein response and thus the regenerative potential of these amphibians, with possible implications for improving healing in mammals.
item.dc:title: Salamanders’ regenerative potential might be driven by a specific protein variant

item.title: Heat-assisted imaging enables day-like visibility at night
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02333-x

An imaging technique that uses a neural-network model to obtain physical information from infrared radiation improves on existing techniques in low-visibility situations, and could be deployed immediately in autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:title: Heat-assisted imaging enables day-like visibility at night
item.dc:creator: Manish Bhattarai
Sophia Thompson

item.title: Meet the scientists planning for disasters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02312-2

Five researchers share what they’ve learnt from studying how to reduce risks and better prepare for natural hazards.
item.dc:title: Meet the scientists planning for disasters
item.dc:creator: Nikki Forrester

item.title: Double-headed molecule activates cell-death pathways in cancer cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02213-4

Molecules have been developed that switch a transcription factor from being a repressor of gene expression to an activator — and thereby able to kill cancer cells. The findings offer a fresh strategy for designing anticancer drugs.
item.dc:title: Double-headed molecule activates cell-death pathways in cancer cells
item.dc:creator: James D. Phelan
Louis M. Staudt

item.title: A neural circuit to support survival in the face of starvation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02114-6

Starvation causes levels of stress hormones called glucocorticoids to rise in the blood. The surge is driven by neuronal cells that produce a peptide called AgRP. These neurons do not excite glucocorticoid-regulating neurons directly, but instead silence neurons that usually constrain the activity of the body’s stress-response system.
item.dc:title: A neural circuit to support survival in the face of starvation

item.title: Why Oppenheimer has important lessons for scientists today
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02409-8

Atomic bomb historian Richard Rhodes talks to Nature about how researchers fare in the film, and what it gets right and wrong.
item.dc:title: Why Oppenheimer has important lessons for scientists today
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Family trees of a Neolithic community uncovered by ancient DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02117-3

Ancient DNA has enabled the reconstruction of two large genetic ‘family trees’ from a 6,700-year-old Neolithic burial site in France called Gurgy ‘Les Noisats’. The DNA data combined with other lines of evidence offer insights into biological relationships within the site and across a broader social and cultural context.
item.dc:title: Family trees of a Neolithic community uncovered by ancient DNA

item.title: The United Kingdom needs to welcome international researchers to thrive
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02367-1

Scientific strength does not come from severing long-standing relationships or turning away talent from around the world.
item.dc:title: The United Kingdom needs to welcome international researchers to thrive

item.title: Seven generations of a prehistoric family mapped with ancient DNA
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02402-1

Unprecedented genealogical tree reveals details of prehistoric social relationships.
item.dc:title: Seven generations of a prehistoric family mapped with ancient DNA
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Global map of wildlife trade reveals true cost to the planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02416-9

By assessing traded animals’ unique traits and their role in ecosystems, researchers can gauge the potential impact of losses.
item.dc:title: Global map of wildlife trade reveals true cost to the planet
item.dc:creator: Sara Phillips

item.title: Long La Niña events could rise in frequency as the planet warms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02331-z

La Niña events involve a cooling of the tropical Pacific Ocean, and can last for two years or more, prolonging their impact. Climate simulations reveal that global warming could cause multi-year La Niña events to become more frequent.
item.dc:title: Long La Niña events could rise in frequency as the planet warms
item.dc:creator: Xian Wu

item.title: Saving tens of millions of children a year from the effects of lead poisoning is a surprisingly solvable problem
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02368-0

Funding to help nations eliminate lead paint and other sources of exposure would avert millions of deaths and one trillion dollars a year in income loss.
item.dc:title: Saving tens of millions of children a year from the effects of lead poisoning is a surprisingly solvable problem
item.dc:creator: Nafisatou Cissé

item.title: Sixty years since the report of global lead pollution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02196-2

The 1963 discovery that even the vast oceans were highly contaminated with lead from car exhausts sparked debate and policy changes that benefited the health of millions — and revolutionized the practices of marine biogeochemistry.
item.dc:title: Sixty years since the report of global lead pollution
item.dc:creator: Jerome Nriagu

item.title: Sharp criticism of controversial ancient-human claims tests eLife’s revamped peer-review model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02415-w

High-profile researchers say small-brained Homo naledi exhibited advanced behaviours such as burials, but peer reviewers say there’s no evidence.
item.dc:title: Sharp criticism of controversial ancient-human claims tests eLife’s revamped peer-review model
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Daily briefing: It’s time to end ‘parachute research’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02422-x

How to conduct equitable collaborations. Plus, mind-reading machines challenge human rights and a 2,000-year-old curry tells the story of how a dish came to southeast Asia.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: It’s time to end ‘parachute research’
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: ChatGPT is a black box: how AI research can break it open
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02366-2

Despite their wide use, large language models are still mysterious. Revealing their true nature is urgent and important.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT is a black box: how AI research can break it open

item.title: ‘A very disturbing picture’: another retraction imminent for controversial physicist
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02401-2

Ranga Dias will have a second paper revoked. A journal’s investigation found apparent data fabrication.
item.dc:title: ‘A very disturbing picture’: another retraction imminent for controversial physicist
item.dc:creator: Dan Garisto

item.title: ChatGPT broke the Turing test — the race is on for new ways to assess AI
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02361-7

Large language models mimic human chatter, but scientists disagree on their ability to reason.
item.dc:title: ChatGPT broke the Turing test — the race is on for new ways to assess AI
item.dc:creator: Celeste Biever

item.title: I’ve witnessed the wonders of the deep sea. Mining could destroy them
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 25 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02369-z

Deep-sea mining could wreck more than just the ocean floor in ways we have no idea how to repair.
item.dc:title: I’ve witnessed the wonders of the deep sea. Mining could destroy them
item.dc:creator: Beth N. Orcutt

item.title: I sample Antarctica’s seaweed to improve human health
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02314-0

Fisheries engineer Ekrem Cem Çankırılıgil probes the chemical make-up of aquatic creatures to determine their possible health benefits for humans.
item.dc:title: I sample Antarctica’s seaweed to improve human health
item.dc:creator: Nic Fleming

item.title: Why heart trouble can lead to sleep trouble
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02343-9

An immune response triggered by cardiac disease affects the function of a gland with a key role in the sleep–wake cycle.
item.dc:title: Why heart trouble can lead to sleep trouble

item.title: Water in the terrestrial planet-forming zone of the PDS 70 disk
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06317-9

Observations with the sensitive mid-infrared spectrometer MIRI on board JWST reveal the presence of a water vapour reservoir in the terrestrial plant-forming zone of the young planetary system PDS 70.
item.dc:title: Water in the terrestrial planet-forming zone of the PDS 70 disk

item.title: Pack up the parachute: why global north–south collaborations need to change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02313-1

Global-south researchers want equal partnerships that value intellectual exchange.
item.dc:title: Pack up the parachute: why global north–south collaborations need to change
item.dc:creator: Virginia Gewin

item.title: Mind-reading machines are coming — how can we keep them in check?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02405-y

Devices that can record and change brain activity will create privacy issues that challenge existing human-rights legislation, say researchers.
item.dc:title: Mind-reading machines are coming — how can we keep them in check?
item.dc:creator: Liam Drew

item.title: Daily briefing: Abnormal protein levels could be an early hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02418-7

Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age. Plus, how living in a Barbie world would mess with your colour perception and the ‘unfathomable’ burden of long COVID.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Abnormal protein levels could be an early hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: How a scholarly spat shaped a century of genetic research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02310-4

A fresh look at the early history of genetics reveals why a simplified view of biological inheritance came to hold sway — and argues for a revision of how genetics is taught today.
item.dc:title: How a scholarly spat shaped a century of genetic research
item.dc:creator: Brian K. Hall

item.title: Hotly awaited structures obtained for the human protein UCP1
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 24 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02334-w

The protein UCP1 helps to release energy as heat in brown fat. Structures of human UCP1 provide crucial information about its mechanism of action, and might aid drug design for obesity and various metabolism-associated complications.
item.dc:title: Hotly awaited structures obtained for the human protein UCP1
item.dc:creator: Michael J. Gaudry
Martin Jastroch

item.title: Nothing strange about this pentaquark’s ‘strangeness’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02258-5

The Large Hadron Collider yields a five-quark particle that includes a ‘strange’ quark, as predicted by theory.
item.dc:title: Nothing strange about this pentaquark’s ‘strangeness’

item.title: Harald zur Hausen, virologist who linked viruses to cancer (1936–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02370-6

Nobel laureate who laid the foundations for vaccines to prevent cervical cancer.
item.dc:title: Harald zur Hausen, virologist who linked viruses to cancer (1936–2023)
item.dc:creator: Michael Baumann
Magnus von Knebel Doeberitz

item.title: Daily briefing: The genetic basis of walking on two legs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02411-0

Genomic regions linked to short arms and lanky legs bore signs of evolutionary selection in humans. Plus, type 1 diabetes surged in children during the pandemic and expeditions in post-war Colombia have found an ecological treasure trove.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: The genetic basis of walking on two legs
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: As COVID-19 cases rose, so did diabetes — no one knows why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02322-0

The spike in childhood type 1 diabetes opened new avenues for researchers to explore the cause of the disease.
item.dc:title: As COVID-19 cases rose, so did diabetes — no one knows why
item.dc:creator: Clare Watson

item.title: Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 21 July 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02374-2

Abnormal levels of certain proteins — many of which have roles outside the brain — could be an early hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease or similar conditions.
item.dc:title: Dementia risk linked to blood-protein imbalance in middle age
item.dc:creator: Lilly Tozer
